abstract.p: List of some upcoming benefit parties in New York

block.p: Stars Come Out for Charity MONDAY -- Bill Cosby, Celine Dion, Placido Domingo, Patti LaBelle, Sid Caesar and Diahann Carroll will be among the performers at a black-tie dinner and dance to benefit the G & P Charitable Foundation for Cancer Research, founded last year to support medical research and provide financial assistance to cancer patients. Milton Berle will be honored, as will Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS Television, and the Duchess of York will speak at the event, at the Sheraton New York. Cocktails at 6. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 486-2575.

A Wine Tasting TUESDAY -- COAP, a program sponsored by the Visiting Nurse Service of New York for children and adolescents whose parents have AIDS or H.I.V., will benefit from a wine tasting from 6 to 8 P.M. at the Lamont Mansion, 107 East 70th Street. Tickets, $50, from (212) 794-6341.

Stars Come Out for Charity MONDAY -- Bill Cosby, Celine Dion, Placido Domingo, Patti LaBelle, Sid Caesar and Diahann Carroll will be among the performers at a black-tie dinner and dance to benefit the G & P Charitable Foundation for Cancer Research, founded last year to support medical research and provide financial assistance to cancer patients. Milton Berle will be honored, as will Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS Television, and the Duchess of York will speak at the event, at the Sheraton New York. Cocktails at 6. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 486-2575.

A Wine Tasting TUESDAY -- COAP, a program sponsored by the Visiting Nurse Service of New York for children and adolescents whose parents have AIDS or H.I.V., will benefit from a wine tasting from 6 to 8 P.M. at the Lamont Mansion, 107 East 70th Street. Tickets, $50, from (212) 794-6341.

''Beloved'' Preview WEDNESDAY -- Danny Glover, a star of the new movie ''Beloved,'' and Kofi Annan, the Secretary General of the United Nations, will speak at a screening of the film in the Trusteeship Council Chamber. The movie will follow a reception at 5:30 on the West Terrace of the Delegates' Dining Room. The evening will benefit the United Nations Development Program. Tickets, $250, or $75 for the movie alone: (888) 488-4735.

Chamber Music Society Gala WEDNESDAY -- Andre Watts, the pianist, will be the host of a concert at Alice Tully Hall celebrating the 30th anniversary of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. Mr. Watts will also perform, along with Dawn Upshaw, the soprano; David Shifrin, the clarinetist, and members of the society. The evening will begin at 6:30 with a Champagne reception. The concert at 8 will be followed by a black-tie dinner. Tickets, $1,000; $150 for the reception and concert, or $50 for the concert, from (212) 875-5783.

Arts Alliance Anniversary THURSDAY -- The Asian American Arts Alliance will celebrate its 15th anniversary with a reception and performance at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue. Performers include Soh Daiko, a taiko drumming ensemble, and Jason Kao Hwang, a jazz violinist. The reception begins at 6:30 and the performance at 8. Tickets, $50, from (212) 941-9208.

Enabling the Disabled THURSDAY -- The International Center for the Disabled will honor John Hockenberry, the NBC News correspondent, and Lawrence J. Toal, the chairman of the Dime Savings Bank of New York, at a black-tie dinner and dance at the Plaza. The Girls Choir of Harlem will perform at the event. Cocktails at 6:30. Tickets, $500, from (212) 585-6088.

Circus Craft THURSDAY -- Phyllis George and Peter Jennings will be the hosts at a dinner and dance at the Pierre to benefit the American Craft Museum. Guy Laliberte, a founder of Cirque du Soleil, will be among the honorees, and members of the troupe will perform. The black-tie evening will begin with a cocktail reception at 7. Tickets, $500, from (212) 956-3535.

Peter Stuyvesant Ball FRIDAY -- The 17th annual Peter Stuyvesant Ball will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria, to benefit the charitable programs of the Netherland-America Foundation. The black-tie evening will include a performance by the Drifters and a live auction conducted by Patrick Meade of Christie's. Cocktails at 6:30 will be followed by dinner and dancing. Tickets, $400, from (212) 355-6363.

Helping the Elderly NEXT SUNDAY -- Dr. Henry A. Kissinger will speak at the annual dinner-dance benefiting the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, in the Bronx. Marc A. Lustgarten, a vice chairman of the Cablevision Systems Corporation, will be honored, Peter Duchin and His Orchestra will play and members of the Radio City Rockettes will perform. The black-tie evening at the Waldorf-Astoria will begin with cocktails at 6. Tickets, $1,000, from (718) 549-3555.

Museum Aid OCT. 19 -- The American Federation of Arts will benefit from a dinner and dance at the Rainbow Room. Iris Cantor, the chairwoman of the Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Foundation, will be honored. The evening will raise money for the organization's traveling art exhibitions program and its services to art museums around the country. Drinks at 7. Black tie. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 988-7700, ext. 47.

For the Jerusalem Foundation OCT. 19 -- Liv Ullmann will be the master of ceremonies for a concert at Avery Fisher Hall to benefit the charitable programs of the Jerusalem Foundation. The performers will include Kathleen Battle and Harolyn Blackwell, the sopranos; Olga Borodina, the mezzo-soprano; Sarah Chang, the violinist, and the American Symphony Orchestra, which will perform the world premiere of ''Psalm 126,'' written for the occasion by Philip Glass and narrated by Paul Sorvino. The black-tie evening will begin with drinks at 5, to be followed by dinner at 6 and the concert at 8. Tickets, $1,250, or $750 for those 35 and under, from (212) 697-4188; tickets for the concert alone are $25 to $100, from (212) 721-6500.

Actors' Theater Dinner OCT. 19 -- The National Actors Theater will benefit from a black-tie dinner at the Plaza. Frank N. Newman, the chief executive of the Bankers Trust Company, and his wife, Lizabeth A. Newman, will be honored. Bill Cosby will perform, and Rosie O'Donnell will preside over a live auction. Cocktails at 6:30. Tickets, $600, from (212) 997-0100.

Dinner and Songs OCT. 19 -- Mary Cleere Haran, the cabaret singer, will perform, accompanied by Richard Rodney Bennett, at a dinner at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, to benefit Theaterworks/USA, which gives performances for young people. Drinks and dancing at 6, followed by the dinner. Tickets, $250, from (212) 647-1100.

Slipping and Sliding OCT. 19 -- James C. Goodale, a partner in the law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, will be honored at a Halloween party at the American Festival Cafe at Rockefeller Plaza, to benefit the Ice Theater of New York. The evening will begin with drinks and open skating on the Plaza rink from 6:30 to 7:30. Dinner at 7:30 will be followed by skating performances by members of the company, Elena Leonova, Andrei Khvalko, Gia Guddat and a troupe of ice acrobats. The organizers encourage guests to wear costumes; prizes will be awarded. Tickets, $150, or $50 for children 14 and under, from (212) 929-5811.

A Century in the City OCT. 20 -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will be honored at the annual dinner of the Hundred Year Association of New York. Richard D. Parsons, the president of Time Warner, will present the award. The evening will raise money for merit awards for New York City civil-service workers and college scholarships for their families. The black-tie evening on the St. Regis Roof will begin with a cocktail reception at 6:30. Tickets, $550, from (212) 922-0791.

Casita Maria Gala OCT. 20 -- John Leguizamo, the comedian and actor, will be among the honorees at a dinner-dance to raise money for the Casita Maria settlement house in the Bronx. The black-tie evening at the Plaza will begin with drinks at 7:30. Tickets, $500, from (212) 807-7535.

New York Treasures OCT. 20 -- The Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue, will hold its annual black-tie dinner and dance. An exhibition of photographs by Gordon Parks will be open during the evening, which begins with a cocktail reception at 7. Tickets, $375, from (212) 534-1672, ext. 253.

Chamber Music OCT. 21 -- Irene Diamond will be honored at Alice Tully Hall on opening night of the New York Chamber Symphony's 22d season. Gerard Schwarz will conduct an all-Mozart program. The performers include Hei-Kyung Hong, a soprano, and Rinat Shaham, a mezzo-soprano. The event begins at 6 P.M. with cocktails and dinner. The concert at 8 is followed by dessert and a live auction. Tickets, $500; $200 for the concert and dessert, or $50 to $100 for the concert, from (212) 262-6927.

For Children With AIDS OCT. 22 -- The Duchess of York will be honored at a dinner-dance for the Incarnation Children's Center, a residence and outpatient clinic in Manhattan for children with H.I.V. and AIDS. Joy Behar, a host of ''The View,'' a talk show on ABC, will be mistress of ceremonies for the black-tie event, at the Copacabana, 617 West 57th Street. Cocktails at 6:30. Tickets, $300; (212) 928-2590, ext. 31.

Helping Healing OCT. 22 -- The Children's Health Fund will hold its annual black-tie dinner at the Pierre. Marc Anthony, the salsa singer, will perform. Cocktails at 6:30. Tickets, $600, from (212) 245-6570.

For Jewish Art OCT. 22 -- The Yeshiva University Museum will celebrate its 25th anniversary with a black-tie dinner at Cipriani Wall Street, 55 Wall Street. Erica Jesselson, who founded the museum with her late husband, Ludwig Jesselson, will be honored. The evening will begin at 6 with a reception and silent auction. Tickets, $600, from (212) 960-0894.
